definition: Chronic high blood pressure — long-term elevated blood pressure that increases load on the heart and arteries.
Low blood pressure — when the blood pressure is below normal values, possibly causing fainting or dizziness.
Abnormally slow heart rate, often under 60 beats per minute at rest.
Abnormally fast heart rate, often over 100 beats per minute at rest.
Irregular or abnormal heartbeat — heart rhythm deviates from normal sinus rhythm.
A common arrhythmia causing rapid and irregular beating of the heart's atria.
Extra, early heartbeats beginning in one of the heart’s ventricles, contributing to irregular rhythm.
Narrowing or blockage of coronary arteries supplying blood to heart muscle, often due to plaque buildup.
Death of part of the heart muscle because of severely reduced or blocked blood supply.
Chest pain or discomfort caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle.
Angina that occurs unpredictably, often more severe and may signal impending myocardial infarction.
Predictable chest pain triggered by exertion or stress and relieved by rest or medication.
Hardening and narrowing of arteries caused by build-up of plaque (fatty deposits, cholesterol), reducing blood flow.
Condition where the heart cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's needs, often causing fluid build-up.
Thickening of the walls of the heart’s left ventricle, often due to long-term high blood pressure or heart disease.
Disease of the heart muscle that reduces its ability to pump blood; can be dilated, hypertrophic, or restrictive type.
Diseases affecting one or more of the heart valves, interfering with blood flow direction or volume.
Narrowing of the aortic valve opening, restricting blood flow from the heart into the aorta.
Leakage of blood backward through the mitral valve each time the left ventricle contracts.
Narrowing of the mitral valve, obstructing blood flow from left atrium to left ventricle.
Inflammation of the pericardium — the thin sac surrounding the heart.
Infection or inflammation of the inner lining of the heart chambers and valves.
Sudden cessation of heart function — heart stops beating effectively.
Structural problems with the heart present from birth (valve defects, septal defects, etc.).
Hole in the wall (septum) that separates left and right sides of the heart (e.g., ASD, VSD).
A persistent opening between two major blood vessels of the heart that fails to close after birth.
A test that records the electrical activity of the heart to identify arrhythmias, heart attack, etc.
Ultrasound imaging of the heart to assess structure, valves, blood flow, and function.
Heart test under controlled physical exertion to evaluate blood flow, rhythm, and ischemia.
Imaging test to visualize coronary arteries, used to detect blockages or narrowing.
Procedure to open narrowed or blocked coronary arteries, often with stent placement.
Surgical procedure to restore blood flow to heart muscle by bypassing blocked coronary arteries.
Implantable device that regulates abnormal heart rhythms by delivering timed electrical impulses.
Device implanted in heart to detect life-threatening arrhythmias and deliver shock to restore normal rhythm.
Procedure to examine heart chambers, valves, and coronary arteries via a thin tube inserted into blood vessels.
Program of exercise, education, and counseling to help patients recover from heart disease or surgery.
Sensation of rapid, fluttering, or pounding heartbeats — often sign of arrhythmia or stress.
Temporary loss of consciousness (fainting) due to insufficient blood flow to the brain, sometimes from heart problems.
Swelling, often in legs/feet, caused by fluid build-up due to heart failure or poor circulation.
Formation of new blood vessels supplying the heart — natural or post-injury adaptation.
Lack of sufficient blood flow (and oxygen) to a part of the heart muscle — can cause angina or MI.
Heart problems caused by narrowed heart arteries resulting in reduced blood flow — includes angina and MI.
Extra or unusual sound heard during heartbeat — may indicate valve problem or other heart defect.
Life-threatening condition where heart can’t pump enough blood to meet the body’s needs — often after MI.
Any heart structural abnormality present at birth (septal defect, valve defect, vascular anomaly, etc.).
Delay or block in electrical conduction on the left side of the heart — visible on ECG.
Delay or block in electrical conduction on the right side of the heart — visible on ECG.
Thickening of heart muscle — often from chronic high blood pressure or valve disease.
Build-up of fluid in the pericardial sac around the heart — can impair heart function.
Abnormal thickening or scarring of the heart’s inner lining (endocardium), often affecting valves.
Weakening and bulging of a heart/aorta wall — risk of rupture, blood flow issues.
Structural changes of the heart (size, shape, function) after injury (like MI) or chronic stress.
Heart valve damage resulting from rheumatic fever (infection-related), causing long-term heart issues.
Heart muscle disease occurring during pregnancy or after delivery causing heart failure symptoms.
High blood pressure in the arteries of the lungs, which can strain the right side of the heart.
Failure of the right ventricle to pump blood effectively, often causing swelling in the legs and abdomen.
Failure of the left ventricle to pump blood effectively, leading to pulmonary congestion and shortness of breath.
Failure of both left and right ventricles, combining symptoms of both right and left heart failure.
Impairment in the heart’s electrical conduction system, slowing or preventing signals from reaching the ventricles.
Minor delay in electrical conduction through the AV node — usually asymptomatic.
Some electrical signals fail to reach the ventricles — may cause dizziness or fainting.
No electrical signals reach the ventricles — can cause severe bradycardia and syncope.
Rapid heart rate originating above the ventricles — often sudden onset and stops spontaneously.
Fast, abnormal heart rhythm originating in the ventricles — can lead to cardiac arrest if untreated.
Life-threatening irregular heart rhythm causing the ventricles to quiver instead of pumping — requires immediate defibrillation.
Genetic condition causing abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, especially the septum, which can obstruct blood flow.
Heart chambers enlarge and weaken, reducing pumping efficiency and causing heart failure.
Heart muscle becomes rigid, restricting filling of the ventricles while systolic function is preserved.
Temporary heart muscle weakness often triggered by severe emotional or physical stress.
Deposition of abnormal proteins in the heart, leading to stiffening and heart failure.
Blockage of a pulmonary artery by a blood clot, causing sudden shortness of breath and possible right heart strain.
Formation of a blood clot in deep veins (usually legs) that can travel to the lungs and cause PE.
Right-sided heart failure due to chronic lung disease or pulmonary hypertension.
Tear in the inner layer of the aorta wall, causing life-threatening bleeding into the vessel wall.
Genetic disorder affecting connective tissue, often causing aortic enlargement and valve issues.
Long-standing congenital heart defect causing pulmonary hypertension and reversal of blood flow.
Life-threatening condition of inadequate tissue perfusion; cardiogenic shock is specifically due to heart failure.
Surgical replacement of a diseased heart with a donor heart in patients with end-stage heart failure.
Mechanical pump that helps the left ventricle pump blood in patients awaiting heart transplant or with severe heart failure.
Life-support machine that oxygenates blood outside the body for patients with severe cardiac or pulmonary failure.
Field focused on managing heart disease risk in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy or radiation.
Variation in time between heartbeats — used as a measure of autonomic nervous system activity and cardiac health.
Small vessel disease of the heart causing angina-like symptoms without large artery blockage.
Inflammatory disease affecting large arteries including the aorta, leading to narrowing and possible heart complications.
Bulging of the ventricular wall, often after myocardial infarction, which may impair function or rupture.
Weakening of arteries supplying the brain or heart, increasing risk of rupture or stroke.
Rapid heartbeat originating from the atria, distinct from atrial fibrillation or flutter.
Common type of supraventricular tachycardia caused by a reentry circuit in the AV node.
Congenital condition where the aortic valve has two leaflets instead of three, can lead to stenosis or regurgitation.
Rare ventricular tachycardia due to reentry circuit within bundle branches.
Chronic narrowing of coronary arteries after heart transplant.
Any abnormality in the electrical pathways of the heart causing arrhythmias or blocks.
Excess fibrous tissue in the heart muscle, leading to stiffness and impaired function.
Medications (like digoxin) that increase heart contractility, used in heart failure and AFib.
Parasitic infection leading to cardiomyopathy and arrhythmias.
Pain in limbs due to reduced blood flow from atherosclerosis; may indicate systemic vascular disease.
Temporary narrowing of coronary arteries causing chest pain, often at rest.
Procedure using extreme cold to destroy abnormal heart tissue causing arrhythmia.
Acute worsening of chronic heart failure symptoms requiring urgent intervention.
Impaired relaxation of the ventricles, often leading to heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.
Congenital malformation affecting atrial and ventricular septa and valves.
Fat deposits on the heart surface associated with coronary artery disease risk.
Abnormal heart rhythm triggered by physical activity.
Genetic disorder causing high LDL cholesterol and premature coronary artery disease.
Replacement of heart muscle with fat tissue, potentially affecting conduction and function.
Occasional failure of electrical signals to pass through AV node.
Measure of autonomic function based on heart rate drop after exercise.
Calcium deposits on valves reducing flexibility, can cause stenosis or regurgitation.
Continuous measurement of blood pressure, cardiac output, and other parameters.
24–48 hour portable ECG monitoring to detect intermittent arrhythmias.
Irregular heartbeat caused by low potassium levels affecting cardiac conduction.
High blood pressure in pulmonary arteries with unknown cause.
Heart muscle inflammation leading to impaired function, often from viral infection.
Disease affecting only the right ventricle, often leading to arrhythmias.
Increase in left atrial size, often due to hypertension or valve disease.
Rare congenital cardiomyopathy with spongy left ventricular muscle.
Genetic disorder causing prolonged QT interval on ECG, increasing risk of sudden cardiac death.
Patch of fibrosis in atrium seen in rheumatic heart disease.
Calcium deposits in mitral valve ring, can impair valve function.
Inflammation of heart muscle, often viral or autoimmune in origin.
Abnormally fast heart rate in newborns.
AFib episodes that start and stop spontaneously.
Small hole between atria that persists after birth, sometimes causing stroke or migraine.
Heart dysfunction related to pregnancy, including peripartum cardiomyopathy.
Pressure overload on right ventricle due to obstruction in pulmonary arteries.
Backward flow of blood through pulmonary valve, often post-surgical or congenital.
Lengthening of QT interval caused by certain medications, increasing arrhythmia risk.
Dysfunction of the sinus node causing bradycardia, pauses, or alternating slow and fast rhythms.
Specific type of ventricular tachycardia associated with prolonged QT interval.
Congenital defect where the aorta and pulmonary artery are reversed, requiring surgery.
Congenital absence or closure of tricuspid valve leading to hypoplastic right ventricle.
Backflow of blood through tricuspid valve during ventricular contraction.
Large hole in ventricular septum causing significant left-to-right shunt.
Pre-excitation syndrome causing abnormal electrical pathways and tachyarrhythmias.
Rapid but regular atrial contractions, often resulting in fast ventricular rate.
Replacement of right ventricular myocardium with fibrofatty tissue, predisposing to VT.
Portable device used to deliver electrical shock to restore normal heart rhythm in emergencies.
Infection of a heart valve replacement device.

term: Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF)
definition: Heart failure where ejection fraction is normal but diastolic dysfunction is present.

term: Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF)
definition: Heart failure with low ejection fraction, indicating systolic dysfunction.
Obstruction in the path from left ventricle to aorta, often in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Floppy mitral valve causing regurgitation, sometimes arrhythmia, or palpitations.
Congenital condition where ventricular myocardium has deep trabeculations.
Intermittent episodes of rapid heartbeat originating above the ventricles.
High blood pressure in pulmonary arteries due to vascular disease.
Thickening of the right ventricular wall, often from pulmonary hypertension.
Fast heart rate originating from the sinus node, often physiologic.
Slow heart rate originating from the sinus node.
Extra heartbeat originating in the atria, usually benign.
Extra heartbeat originating in the ventricles, may cause palpitations.
Changes in ECG or imaging indicating increased left ventricular workload, often from hypertension.
Signs of increased right ventricular workload, often from pulmonary embolism or pulmonary hypertension.
Narrowing of the pulmonary valve, causing right ventricular pressure overload.
Backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole.
Range of conditions including unstable angina and myocardial infarction due to sudden coronary artery blockage.
Delayed coronary blood flow without large vessel obstruction, causing angina.
Measures heart and lung function during exercise to assess cardiovascular fitness.
Procedure to close left atrial appendage to reduce stroke risk in AFib.
Implantable sensor that monitors pulmonary artery pressure in heart failure patients.
Segment of a coronary artery tunneled under heart muscle, potentially causing ischemia.
Transient heart muscle dysfunction often triggered by stress (includes Takotsubo syndrome).
Abnormal dilation of coronary arteries, potentially causing ischemia or thrombosis.
Granulomatous inflammation of heart tissue, which can cause arrhythmias and heart failure.
Thickened or scarred pericardium restricting heart filling.
Procedure to prevent atrial fibrillation by ablating abnormal electrical pathways in pulmonary veins.
Rare growths in the heart, benign (myxoma) or malignant (angiosarcoma).
Uncoordinated contraction of left ventricle, often treated with biventricular pacing.
Increase in size of right atrium due to pressure or volume overload.
Congenital abnormal origin or path of coronary arteries, sometimes causing ischemia.
Temporary heart muscle weakness caused by physical or emotional stress.
Asynchronous contraction of ventricles, may worsen heart failure.
Increased cardiac output due to conditions like anemia or thyrotoxicosis.
Benign tumor usually in the left atrium that can obstruct blood flow.
Measurement reflecting left atrial pressure, used in heart failure evaluation.
Early diastolic sound associated with constrictive pericarditis.
Genetic disorder causing abnormal ECG patterns and increased risk of sudden cardiac death.
